Title.evidence: We performed a randomized controlled trial using a radiostereometric analysis

Trial_Design.evidence: This parallel-group trial (ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT01966848 ) randomized 50 patients

Participants.evidence: randomized 50 patients with an intact ACL who were eligible to undergo TKA

Intervention.evidence: randomized 50 patients...to receive either a bicruciate-retaining or cruciate-retaining TKA

Objective.evidence: We performed a randomized controlled trial using a radiostereometric analysis and asked, at 2 years: (1) Is there a difference in tibial implant migration between the bicruciate-retaining and cruciate-retaining TKA designs?

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the maximum total point motion (MTPM) of the tibial component measured with model-based radiostereometric analysis (RSA) at 2 years postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were blinded to treatment allocation.

Blinding.evidence: Patients were blinded to treatment allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: randomized 50 patients with an intact ACL

Number_Analysed.evidence: RSA images were available for 22 patients who underwent bicruciate-retaining and 23 patients who underwent cruciate-retaining TKA, while patient-reported outcome measures were available for 24 patients in each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The median (interquartile range [IQR]) MTPM was 0.52 mm (0.35 to 1.02) and 0.42 mm (0.34 to 0.70) in the bicruciate-retaining and cruciate-retaining groups, respectively (p = 0.63).

Harms.evidence: Three patients in the bicruciate-retaining group underwent arthroscopically assisted manipulation at 3 to 4 months postoperatively, and one patient in the bicruciate-retaining group sustained a tibial island fracture during primary surgery and underwent a revision procedure after 6 months.
